item.title: Europe's Borders to Reopen for Summer, but Not Everyone Is Invited
item.description: European Union countries should remove borders within the bloc and some neighboring states on June 15 and allow citizens from selected countries outside the bloc to return from July 1, the European Commission said

item.title: Turkish Court Sentences U.S. Consulate Worker to Prison
item.description: Metin Topuz, a Turkish national, was sentenced to nearly nine years in prison on terrorism-related charges, which he denies. The U.S. says it sees no credible evidence to support the conviction.

item.title: Middle East's Coronavirus Surge Shows Pandemic's Shift to Developing World
item.description: The emergence in the Middle East of a quick second wave of coronavirus cases highlights the risk of re-openings in big population centers with often ill-equipped health-care infrastructure.

item.title: China's Trillion-Dollar Campaign Fuels a Tech Race With the U.S.
item.description: China has embarked on a new trillion-dollar push to develop next-generation technologies such as artificial intelligence, data centers, mobile communications, in an effort to catapult the communist nation ahead of the U.S. in critical areas.

item.title: Argentine Farmers, President Clash Over Government Seizure
item.description: Argentina’s leftist government is moving to seize one of the country’s leading agricultural companies, Vicentin, putting President Alberto Fernández in direct conflict with the powerful farming sector.

item.title: Hit Hard by Coronavirus, Russia Joins Global Race for a Vaccine
item.description: Russia is deploying its military and pushing the private sector to deliver on President Vladimir Putin’s demand for a vaccine by the fall, a race likened to the 1960s space race.
